section.title: Introduction
section.subsection: The widely scattered islands were first charted in 1803, but they were too small to host any permanent human habitation. The 1870s and 1880s, saw attempts at guano mining, but these were soon abandoned. The islands became an Australian territory in 1969 and its boundaries were extended in 1997. A small meteorological staff has operated on the Willis Islets since 1921, and several other islands host unmanned weather stations, beacons, and lighthouses. Much of the territory lies within marine national nature reserves. Â

section.title: Geography
section.subsection: Oceania, islands in the Coral Sea, northeast of Australia

section.title: People and Society
section.subsection: (July 2021 est.) no indigenous inhabitants there is a staff of four at the meteorological station on Willis Island

subsection.title: Children under the age of 5 years underweight

section.title: Environment
section.subsection: no permanent freshwater resources; damaging activities include coral mining, destructive fishing practices (overfishing, blast fishing)

section.title: Government

subsection.title: Country name
subsection.note: self-descriptive name to reflect the islands' position in the Coral Sea off the northeastern coast of Australia

section.subsection: territory of Australia; administered from Canberra by the Department of Regional Australia, Local Government, Arts and Sport
the common law legal system of Australia applies where applicable
the flag of Australia is used

section.title: Communications
section.subsection: automatic weather stations on many of the isles and reefs relay data to the mainland

section.title: Military and Security
section.subsection: defense is the responsibility of Australia
